intro: Piper aduncum var. sigualense, commonly known as Brazilian pepper tree or erva-de-santo-antónio, is a tropical plant native to Central and South America. It is a small to medium-sized shrub or tree that typically grows in humid, shaded environments. The plant has compound leaves with opposite arrangement and produces small, clustered flowers followed by fleshy, red berries. It is often found in lowland rainforests and is valued for its ornamental and medicinal properties. The species is also used in traditional medicine for its purported anti-inflammatory and antiseptic effects.
